Comment: I work in the ecomm industry and a lot of places are actually doing this, even though it's a pain in the ass to implement.  No one *ever* shows details about a product's costs, so this is fairly unprecedented.  Websites and orgs don't even have the code to present this information because it's all hidden from front end systems behind ERPs and the like.      What's funny is that everyone's pretending super hard that all this work isn't basically a political protest as much as it's a PR move.  "The rest of the industry is implementing tariffs this way, so we're doing that, too.  It's a hassle, but it's 'industry-standard' so what can we do?"     Everyone's acting like showing the portion of the price caused by the tariff is just basic SOX compliance or something, despite the fact that tariffs in general are not new and no one has ever done this before, *and* no one has ever asked them to do it.   The opposite in fact, the WH has been asking everyone to stop and the online retail industry is just ignoring them ü§£
